title: Easy Ways to Clean Your Dishwasher with Vinegar (and When to Do It)

steps.title: Place a container with white vinegar on the top rack.
steps.content: Place a container with white vinegar on the top rack. Pour 1 cup (240 ml) of distilled white vinegar into a dishwasher-safe bowl or cup. Place the container upright on the top rack in your dishwasher for the most thorough cleaning. [1] X Research source Cleaning professional Chris Willatt mentions that vinegar is effective because it’s acidic and removes hard water build-up.

steps.title: Run a hot-water cycle on your dishwasher.
steps.content: Run a hot-water cycle on your dishwasher. Press the high-temperature wash or the sanitation wash cycle on your dishwasher and let the cycle run. Throughout the cycle, the vinegar and water will move through the machine and clear out any debris and hard water stains. [2] X Research source If you notice really stubborn hard water stains on the bottom of your dishwasher, open the door halfway through the wash cycle. Let the vinegar sit for 20 minutes before closing the door and resuming the cycle. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Open your dishwasher to let it air-dry.
steps.content: Open your dishwasher to let it air-dry. When the cycle finishes, crack open the dishwasher door to let in fresh air. Let the dishwasher dry out completely so you can check for any problem areas. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Empty large food particles out from the dishwasher drain.
steps.content: Empty large food particles out from the dishwasher drain. Locate the drain at the bottom of your dishwasher and look for any large pieces of food or buildup that were dislodged during the cleaning cycle. Pick the debris out by hand or use a damp cloth to wipe the pieces out. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Wipe any spots still inside of your dishwasher.
steps.content: Wipe any spots still inside of your dishwasher. Check inside of your dishwasher for any residual spots or marks that the vinegar didn’t reach. Dampen a cloth with vinegar or soapy water, and wipe down the interior of the machine. Once the spot disappears, then wipe it off with a clean cloth to dry the area. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Soak the dishwasher filter in warm water and vinegar.
steps.content: Soak the dishwasher filter in warm water and vinegar. The dishwasher filter is usually located at the bottom corner of the machine. To remove the filter, twist it and pull it straight out. To clean the filter , soak it for 20 minutes in a sink full of warm water, 1–2 cups (240–470 ml) of vinegar, and a squirt of dish soap. [7] X Research source When you’re finished, rinse the filter with clean water before reinstalling it in your dishwasher.

steps.title: Pour vinegar and baking soda down the dishwasher drain.
steps.content: Pour vinegar and baking soda down the dishwasher drain. Start by heating 1 cup (240 ml) of vinegar in your microwave for 15-20 seconds. Then, stir in 2 tablespoons (34 g) of baking soda. Pour the solution into the bottom of your dishwasher and leave it for 10-15 minutes. To finish cleaning the drain , slowly pour a pot of boiling water in your dishwasher to clear out any debris. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Unclog the spray arms with a toothpick.
steps.content: Unclog the spray arms with a toothpick. The spray arms spread water throughout the dishwasher, but sometimes they can get clogged with debris. Inspect the holes along the edges of the spray arm. If you notice debris stuck in them, pry it out with a toothpick or wire. [9] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source Many times, you can remove the spray arms to access them better. Check for a knob that you can turn by hand or a screw to loosen them.

steps.title: Scrub the door seals and gaskets with soapy water.
steps.content: Scrub the door seals and gaskets with soapy water. Wet a clean cloth with warm water and a squirt of dish soap. Gently scrub the rubber seals around the edge of your dishwasher and door to remove any buildup or mildew on the surface. When you’re finished, wipe them with a dry cloth. [10] X Research source Avoid using vinegar to clean any rubber gaskets. The acidity in vinegar can cause the gaskets to dry out and crack, which could make your dishwasher leak.\

steps.title: Wipe the exterior with a damp soapy cloth.
steps.content: Wipe the exterior with a damp soapy cloth. Close your dishwasher and gently clean the outside with your cloth. Try to remove any marks or fingerprints from the surface. Then, buff the exterior dry with a clean cloth. [11] X Research source If there are stubborn areas, wet a soft toothbrush and gently scrub your dishwasher.

steps.title: Clean your dishwasher with vinegar once a month.
steps.content: Clean your dishwasher with vinegar once a month. Cleaning at least once a month will help get rid of food and bacteria before it has a chance to build up. [12] X Research source Avoid using vinegar every time you run your dishwasher because it’s acidic and could damage plastic or rubber parts inside of your dishwasher.

steps.title: Sprinkle baking soda in your dishwasher to help remove odors.
steps.content: Sprinkle baking soda in your dishwasher to help remove odors. Cleaning professional Raymond Chiu recommends adding 1 cup (272 g) of baking soda at the bottom of your dishwasher and running a hot water cycle. If there are still stubborn spots, he recommends making a paste of baking soda and water, and gently scrubbing your dishwasher with circular motions. Try cleaning with baking soda after using vinegar for the most thorough cleaning and deodorizing.

steps.title: Use a commercial dishwasher cleaner for the best results.
steps.content: Use a commercial dishwasher cleaner for the best results. Add the cleaner directly to the detergent compartment when your dishwasher is empty. Start a normal wash cycle so the cleaner moves through the machine and removes hard water spots and buildup on the surface. [13] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source

steps.title: Try using bleach for the most stubborn marks and stains.
steps.content: Try using bleach for the most stubborn marks and stains. Rather than using vinegar, fill a dishwasher-safe dish with 1 cup (240 ml) of bleach and set it on the top rack. Run the hottest cycle on your dishwasher and open the door when it’s finished to let the machine air-dry. [14] X Research source Chiu says to avoid using bleach if you’re cleaning a stainless steel dishwasher because it could cause damage instead of cleaning.

steps.title: Scrape excess food off your dishes.
steps.content: Scrape excess food off your dishes. Before you put any dishes in your dishwasher, clear your plate into the trash to get rid of large food particles. That way, they won’t get caught in the filter or drain when your dishwasher runs. [15] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source If you’re running your dishwasher right away, you don’t have to rinse your plate off. If you’re waiting to start your dishwasher, give a quick rinse to your dishes so food doesn’t harden to the surface.

steps.title: Run hot water in your sink before starting your dishwasher.
steps.content: Run hot water in your sink before starting your dishwasher. Turn your kitchen faucet to the hottest setting and let it run until the water feels hot. That way, only hot water enters your dishwasher and more effectively removes food and debris from inside. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Keep your dishwasher open to prevent mold and odors.
steps.content: Keep your dishwasher open to prevent mold and odors. Rather than closing your dishwasher, leave it cracked so moisture can evaporate. When your dishwasher is dry, it’s harder for mold to form so it will look and smell good in between cleanings. [17] X Research source

steps.title: What is the best kind of vinegar for cleaning a dishwasher?
steps.content: What is the best kind of vinegar for cleaning a dishwasher? Cleaning professional James Sears recommends distilled white vinegar for cleaning your dishwasher. If it’s been a while since you’ve cleaned your dishwasher and you want a stronger solution, then try cleaning vinegar with more acidity.

steps.title: Can you use vinegar if there are dishes in the dishwasher?
steps.content: Can you use vinegar if there are dishes in the dishwasher? No, avoid using vinegar when your dishwasher is full of dishes. The acids in the vinegar could react with leftover salt on your dishes and cause discoloration on silverware and metal. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Can you use dish soap in your dishwasher?
steps.content: Can you use dish soap in your dishwasher? Avoid using dish soap as a replacement for detergent. Sears mentions that “dish soap creates excessive suds…which will overflow from the machine and spill onto the floor.” Stick to using standard dishwasher detergent whenever you ruin the machine. [19] X Research source It’s okay to use dish soap to spot clean in your dishwasher. Just be sure to wipe any suds away with a damp cloth before you run the next cycle.
